data.title: Kevin Mitchell: 100 years ago, Saskatchewan's first brush with the Grey Cup was a muddy, humbling affair
data.meta_description: It's Regina's first Grey Cup, a bleak little affair. 100 years of tales, traumas and sporadic joys followed, season by season; game by game.
data.text:
Article content

The 1923 Grey Cup ended with this little tradition, which no longer exists: The game ball was thrown into the air, and players went after it — bodies crashing, arms flailing, each man trying for a personal souvenir.

William Creighton, one of the Regina Rugby Club’s bigger players and a survivor of the Great War, emerged with the leather after what the Regina Leader called a “bitter struggle.” It occupied a spot in his kit bag on the train-ride home.

Article content

That football, deadpanned the Leader after Regina’s 54-0 loss to Queen’s University, commanded “a great deal of reverence, much like that accorded a captured Hun bomb.”

And that’s how Saskatchewan’s first-ever brush with the Grey Cup — a century ago — ended. An ugly loss, which even today remains the most lopsided ever, and then a mad scramble.

“It’s the worst sporting disaster that has ever happened to the west,” the Edmonton Journal wrote indignantly, “and will take a long time to live down.”

It started, a few months earlier, with a sparse first workout and a plea in the paper for players to attend practice.

The Regina Rugby Club — nicknamed “Roughriders” or “Rough Riders” by papers outside the city, but not yet in Regina — were far removed from today’s high-definition television appearances and 33,000-seat gridiron palaces. They were amateurs, bolstered by one coach, a general manager, and a trainer.

The Grey Cup, meanwhile, was firmly planted in eastern Canada. The Edmonton Eskimos were the first western team to take a crack at it: They lost 23-0 to the Toronto Argonauts in 1921. In 1922, the Edmonton Elks lost 13-1 to Queen’s.

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

The west pined for its first victory, but 1923 did not start smoothly for the aspirational Regina Rugby Club.

“The squad has a hard old grind ahead,” reported the Leader on Sept. 10, “for the boys have been regarding the future too lightly and have failed to turn out at full strength for practice. Several of the best ruggerists in town, especially Leigh, Milne, Rowand, Bird and Blacklock, have been so wedded to baseball that they have almost forgotten that there is such a game as rugby. These men will have to step fast if they are going to get a place on the team this fall.”

They trickled in. Soon a full squad was on the field, getting noticed.

Captain Tare Rennebohm, a lineman, “is going great guns and ready to face the barrier right now”; end Stew Leigh “pulls them down anything but tenderly”; Howie Milne “is hitting the line like a battering ram”; Scotty McEachern is “elusive as an eel”; Jack Arnot and Curtis Bates “will be buckling on the armour again in a few days and the addition of these two stars will round out a team which should prove worthy representatives of the capital.”

Article content

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

How much have things changed in a century? In 1923, a problem cropped up: The Roughriders were set to play six games against the Saskatoon Quakers, but it looked like Saskatoon might not get a team together.

Regina had dominated its northern rivals dating back more than a decade, with the exception of a 1921 provincial-final upset, and Saskatoon football was hurting.

On Sept. 29, the two cities finally met in the first of four contests — Saskatoon after just four days of practice — and the Roughriders eked out a 6-0 victory, causing a bit of anxiety in the Queen City.

“Saskatoon’s senior rugby squad,” wrote the Saskatoon Star, “is not near so rotten as some crepe hangers would lead one to believe.”

The following week, at Regina’s Park Hughes, the hosts beat Saskatoon 15-5.

Then, controversy. Saskatoon led 3-1 in the dying seconds of their third game, when McEachern returned a punt to the Quakers’ 20 yard line. A Saskatoon player was injured on the play; the referee blew his whistle, but it went unnoticed on the field. McEachern drop-kicked the ball through the uprights, and Regina thought it had won 4-3.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

In the bedlam, and with fans on the field, Regina players departed, many heading into downtown Saskatoon. Back at the park, it was determined that not only was the score still 3-1, but there was also time on the clock.

Regina didn’t have enough players on hand to finish, so it forfeited, and took its first loss of the season.

Saskatoon needed to win bout No. 4 to send the series to a one-game playoff, and a chance of dashing Regina’s Grey Cup hopes. It was a nasty affair, with a fourth-quarter brawl. Fans ran onto the field to join the fray.

Regina’s 15-10 victory sent it to the western semifinal against the Edmonton Eskimos. Regina won 9-6, setting up a western final against the Winnipeg Victorias. A Grey Cup berth was on the line. Regina won 11-1, and was off to the dominion championship.

Nobody knew what to expect from the western squad. Guess-work, all around.

Queen’s clinched the eastern title with a 13-5 victory over the Hamilton Tigers, and on the night of Nov. 26, Regina’s squad — backed by local fund-raising and a promised cut of the game receipts — put 19 players onto a Toronto-bound train, along with coach Jack Eadie, general manager Al Ritchie and trainer Jimmy Thompson.

Advertisement 6

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

On Thursday, Regina’s players, wearing red and black uniforms, trotted onto the Toronto field for a practice session before hundreds of curious onlookers. According to the Leader, they were eager “to see these men from the great West show their stuff.”

Some reports touched on the team’s presumed speed and size, but renowned Toronto Star sportswriter Lou Marsh was unimpressed. They didn’t look good, he opined; so bad, in fact, that one might think it was a ruse.

“Some of the red and black players,” he wrote, “did some things so badly that it looked as if they were out there to kid the natives.”

CLICK HERE FOR COMPLETE GREY CUP COVERAGE

For more stories, a festival schedule and everything you want to know about the CFL championship in Regina, go to the Leader-Post’s Grey Cup section.

He did profess an admiration for the “baby elephant” size of Creighton, Bill Kerr, Tare Rennebohm and Jerry Crapper.

The field was buried in ankle-deep mud following a 24-hour rain, which was thought to favour Regina, even if nothing else did.

The Leader’s optimistic game-day headline, in big letters:

Advertisement 7

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

QUEENS WILL MEET STRONGEST TEAM

THAT EVER CAME OUT OF THE WEST

IN DOMINION FINAL TODAY, IS VIEW

On Monday:

QUEENS SMOTHER WESTERN CHAMPIONS

Regina trailed 20-0 at halftime, and 43-0 after three quarters before a crowd of 8,528. Their only scoring opportunity came in the second quarter, when McEachern drop-kicked a 15-yard field-goal attempt into the line of scrimmage.

Howie Milne, inducted into the Roughriders’ Plaza of Honour in 1992, was one of the team’s few bright spots. He had two long carries, and “crawled out from under mountains of flesh time after time, when Regina succeeded in stopping Queen’s advance.”

There wasn’t much else to say. That team still holds the Grey Cup record for most points allowed, Creighton got the game ball, and the Roughriders made seven more appearances — all of them without winning — until they beat Ottawa 29-14 in 1966.

Players never forgot that day.

“For those — like Tare Rennebohm — who played in this debacle, it was a humiliation forever seared in their memories, a score to be referred to defensively as the ‘five-four-oh!’ game,” wrote Bob Calder and Garry Andrews in their 1984 history book ‘Rider Pride.’

Advertisement 8

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

A British Pathe crew filmed the contest for a silent short they called “No Game For Weaklings!” and it can be viewed on YouTube nearly 100 years later. The camera pans Regina players on the sidelines, shows footage of a chained bear, and then moves to bits of the game — black-and-white players run and dodge on the sodden field; there’s a fumble, a roaring crowd, a long Queen’s run.

It’s Regina’s first Grey Cup, a bleak little affair, sprung from the dead through moving pictures. One hundred years of tales, traumas and sporadic joys followed, season by season; game ball by game ball.

kemitchell@postmedia.com
